On this Labor Day, take a moment to reflect on the work of African-American activists who fought for fair wages and better working conditions. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s last campaign before his death was with the sanitation workers on strike in Memphis in 1968.

“Our needs are identical with labor’s needs: decent wages, fair working conditions, livable housing, old-age security, health and welfare measures, conditions in which families can grow, have education for their children, and respect in the community,” King told the AFL-CIO annual convention in 1961.

Learn more about “I am a man” sanitation strike at https://www.commondreams.org/views/2016/09/05/labor-day-remember-martin-luther-kings-last-campaign-was-workers-rights

University City Mayor Terry Crow and other mayors in the region are hosting Mayors For Meals curbside drop-and-go food collection sites around the region to help restock the St. Louis Area Foodbank. Donations will be accepted this Saturday, May 9, from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. on the semi-circle driveway in front of the District's McNair Administration Building, 8136 Groby Road (63130). Food items needed include unsweetened applesauce, peanut butter, instant oatmeal packets, cereal, skillet dinners and canned items: chicken, tuna, corn, peas, chili with beans, peaches, Spaghetti O's and more.

post_text:
The District's Grab & Go meal program has served more than 65,000 meals to students since schools and cafeterias were shut down in response to COVID-19. The University City Education Foundation has already raised more than $30,000 in its Summer Meal Appeal to provide families in the District with weekly care packages through the summer months featuring fresh produce, snacks and essential items - half of its goal. We are so grateful for these milestones and the incredible community action that has taken place to support the well-being of our students and families. Read the whole story at www.ucityschools.org/GrabandGoUpdate.

(Photo by Colter Peterson, St. Louis Post-Dispatch)
